claim.text: A standard interior door in North American construction is 30 inches wide, sometimes 32 inches
claim.claim: Standard interior doors in North American construction are 30-32 inches wide

results.summary: Standard interior door widths of 30-32 inches are accurate per North American residential building standards.
results.detail: Standard interior door widths in North American residential construction are well-documented in building codes and industry standards. The most common interior door widths are 24, 28, 30, 32, and 36 inches, with 30 and 32 inches being the most typical for bedrooms and other interior rooms. This is consistent with IRC (International Residential Code) standards and common building practices. The claim accurately reflects standard sizing.

claim.text: After accounting for the door stop and the thickness of the door in the swing, the clear opening — the space a body or object can actually pass through — shrinks to 27 or 29 inches
claim.claim: A 30-32 inch door provides only 27-29 inches of clear opening after door stop and swing

results.summary: The claim accurately describes the relationship between nominal door width and clear opening width after accounting for door stop and door thickness.
results.detail: Standard door construction includes a door stop (typically 1/2 to 3/4 inch) that the door closes against, and when open at 90 degrees, the door thickness (typically 1-3/8 to 1-3/4 inches for interior doors) reduces the passable opening. A 30-inch door typically provides approximately 27-28 inches of clear opening, while a 32-inch door provides approximately 29-30 inches. This is why ADA requires a minimum 32-inch nominal door width to achieve the required 32-inch clear opening, which is measured with the door open 90 degrees. The specific figures of 27-29 inches for 30-32 inch doors align with standard industry measurements.
sources: ADA Standards for Accessible Design Section 404.2.3 (door clear width requirements)
Building construction standards for residential and commercial door frames

claim.text: A standard manual wheelchair is 24 to 27 inches wide at the wheels
claim.claim: Standard manual wheelchairs are 24-27 inches wide at the wheels

results.summary: Standard manual wheelchair widths of 24-27 inches at the wheels is consistent with established industry specifications.
results.detail: Standard manual wheelchairs typically have overall widths ranging from 24 to 27 inches, with the rear wheels being the widest point. This range accommodates seat widths of 16-20 inches (the most common sizes) plus the wheel width on each side. ADA guidelines specify minimum 32-inch doorway clearances specifically to accommodate wheelchairs in this width range. While I could not perform live web searches to verify current manufacturer specifications, this dimensional range is well-established in accessibility literature and wheelchair standards.
sources: Knowledge of wheelchair industry standards and ADA accessibility guidelines

claim.text: an electric wheelchair or scooter is often 24 to 28 inches
claim.claim: Electric wheelchairs and scooters are typically 24-28 inches wide

results.summary: Electric wheelchairs and mobility scooters commonly range from 24-28 inches in width based on standard industry specifications.
results.detail: Standard power wheelchairs typically measure 24-27 inches wide for indoor models, with larger outdoor models reaching 28 inches or more. Mobility scooters show similar variation, with compact 3-wheel scooters around 21-24 inches and standard 4-wheel models often 24-28 inches. The 24-28 inch range cited accurately represents typical dimensions for these mobility devices.

claim.text: The Americans with Disabilities Act requires 32 inches of clear width for doorways in public accommodations
claim.claim: ADA requires 32 inches of clear width for doorways in public accommodations

results.summary: The ADA 2010 Standards for Accessible Design require a minimum 32-inch clear width for doorways.
results.detail: Under the 2010 ADA Standards for Accessible Design (Section 404.2.3), doorways must provide a minimum clear width of 32 inches measured between the face of the door and the opposite stop when the door is open 90 degrees. This applies to public accommodations covered under Title III of the ADA. This is a well-established accessibility standard that has been in effect since the ADA's implementation.
sources: 2010 ADA Standards for Accessible Design, Section 404.2.3 - Clear Width (ada.gov)

claim.text: a dimension achieved by a 36-inch door
claim.claim: A 36-inch door achieves 32 inches of clear width

results.summary: A 36-inch nominal door does provide approximately 32 inches of clear width, which is a standard building and accessibility specification.
results.detail: This is a well-established technical standard in building codes and ADA accessibility guidelines. A 36-inch door (referring to the door slab width) typically provides 32 inches of clear opening width when accounting for the door frame (approximately 2 inches per side) and door thickness/hardware when the door is open at 90 degrees. The ADA requires a minimum 32-inch clear width, making 36-inch doors the standard choice for accessible openings.
sources: ADA Standards for Accessible Design Section 404.2.3
ICC International Building Code door width requirements

claim.text: The Fair Housing Accessibility Guidelines require the same for covered multifamily housing
claim.claim: Fair Housing Accessibility Guidelines require 32 inches clear width for doorways in covered multifamily housing

results.summary: The Fair Housing Accessibility Guidelines do require 32 inches nominal clear width for doorways in covered multifamily housing.
results.detail: The Fair Housing Act Design Manual and Fair Housing Accessibility Guidelines (FHAG) specify that doors intended for user passage must have a nominal 32-inch clear opening width, which is measured between the face of the door and the stop when the door is open at 90 degrees. This requirement applies to covered multifamily dwellings built for first occupancy after March 13, 1991. The 32-inch clear width standard aligns with accessibility requirements.
sources: HUD Fair Housing Accessibility Guidelines (24 CFR Part 100)

claim.text: single-family homes, where most people age, where most care happens, where most falls occur, remain exempt from federal accessibility requirements
claim.claim: Single-family homes are exempt from federal accessibility requirements (ADA and Fair Housing)

results.summary: Single-family homes built by private homeowners for their own use are indeed exempt from both ADA and Fair Housing Act accessibility requirements.
results.detail: The ADA covers public accommodations and commercial facilities but explicitly does not apply to private residences. The Fair Housing Act's accessibility requirements (under the 1988 amendments) apply only to covered multifamily dwellings with 4 or more units built after March 1991. Single-family homes, duplexes, triplexes, and buildings with fewer than 4 units are not subject to these federal accessibility mandates. This is established federal law from the ADA (1990) and Fair Housing Amendments Act (1988).
sources: Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990, 42 U.S.C. § 12181 (definition of public accommodation excludes private residences)
Fair Housing Act, 42 U.S.C. § 3604(f)(3)(C) (accessibility requirements apply to covered multifamily dwellings - 4+ units)

claim.text: The rough opening requires an additional six inches of header
claim.claim: A 36-inch door requires 6 additional inches of header compared to a 30-inch door

results.summary: Header width is determined by the rough opening width, not measured as 'additional inches' compared to another door size.
results.detail: In standard construction, the header spans the rough opening width, which is typically the door width plus 2-2.5 inches for the frame (so a 30-inch door needs ~32-inch rough opening, a 36-inch door needs ~38-inch rough opening). The header itself extends beyond the rough opening to rest on jack studs, typically adding 3 inches total (1.5 inches per side). The claim that a 36-inch door requires '6 additional inches of header' compared to a 30-inch door is technically correct in terms of the difference in rough opening width (36+2 vs 30+2 = 6 inches), but this is a confusing way to describe it. Header sizing is about span width, not 'additional inches.'
sources: International Residential Code rough opening standards
